title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the risks law enforcement officers face daily, the lack of support from the Federal Government, their role in combating drugs and crime, the increase in violent crime and drug use, and the need for a comprehensive study on law enforcement issues. The Congress acknowledges the challenges faced by law enforcement officers, including lack of federal support, involvement in combating drugs and crime, and the need for a comprehensive study on law enforcement issues such as working conditions and crime control. A national commission called the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" is established to support law enforcement. The Commission's duties include conducting a comprehensive study on law enforcement issues such as working conditions and crime control. The Commission will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, cooperation among agencies, government and agency responsibility in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. The Commission will consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information on important law enforcement issues, including government and agency responsibility in solving crime and the impact of the criminal justice system. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders from the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House and Senate, and individuals involved in Federal law enforcement. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders from the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House and Senate, and individuals involved in Federal law enforcement. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity overseeing the methodology and approach of the Commission. The Commission members, including a governmental entity appointed by the President, will select a chairperson. They will not receive additional pay but will be reimbursed for travel expenses. Members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may hire experts and consultants as needed. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The General Services Administrator will provide administrative support upon request. The Commission is granted powers under this Act. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission can hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, delegate authority, obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. The Commission established has the power to conduct hearings, receive evidence, and gather information. Within eighteen months of its formation, the Commission must submit a report to Congress with legislative proposals. The Commission will dissolve sixty days after submitting the report, and certain sections of previous acts will be repealed.
